reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: The Silent Age
Original Release: 2015
Genre Tags: Point & Click; Puzzle; Adventure; Casual
My Overall Grade: B+
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 3-5 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: None
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Puzzle game aficionados; Casual gamers
REVIEWThe Silent Age is an easy and short point-and-click game that I felt was subtly very charming.  There isn’t anything about this game that is groundbreaking or excessively impressive, but it still comes together to make for an enjoyable experience.  If you are a fan of point-and-click adventure games, you should probably check this out.

The narrative of the game is probably its best quality.  The story is rather cliché, revolving around time-travel and prevention of the apocalypse.  But the way in which the story unfolds is intriguing, and I found myself enjoying the tale even though it was far from novel.  Moreover, the pacing of the story was perfect, with plot developments timed at just the right moments to keep me interested.

The puzzles are inventory-based, and are all very logical and intuitive.  There won’t be any points in the game where you will find yourself saying: “that solution makes no sense.”  That may not seem like something worth mentioning, but, unfortunately, many point-and-click games have puzzle solutions that don’t make much sense.  Luckily, in The Silent Age, all of the puzzle solutions are reasonable.   Due to this, and the fact that there aren’t many inventory items to be found, the game inevitably is quite simple.  The time-travel dynamic, while not groundbreaking, does spice up some of the puzzle-solving and undoubtedly makes the game more interesting.

The Silent Age boils down to a story-driven, casual experience that is great for times you may want to play something that is low-pressure and that you can’t really mess up.  There is even a well-crafted level select system so you don’t even have to worry about missable achievements.  I would recommend it to big fans of point-and-click adventure games.  It is rather short and simple, however, and anyone on the fence regarding the genre may find it somewhat lacking.

reviewText:
The Silent Age is a short point-and-click adventure revolving around time travel. In my opinion, the story isn't anything amazing and is quite linear, but it can hold your attention and is integrated well with the nature of the game. Controls consist of clicking left or right to move the character and on objects to interact. The puzzles involve switching between different time periods and are fairly simple so they don't interfere much with the pace of the story.

The presentation is clean and simple. The soundtrack is great at creating a sense of suspense throughout the game, but the voice acting can be hit or miss for some. Also, most of the time I spent in the game was looking at descriptions which loaded up fairly slowly. If they were to load as fast as the time switching, a sizeable amount of play time could be chopped off.

You'll likely obtain most of the achievements by the time you complete the game as they are fairly easy to get. Since the game is organized into chapters, you can easily hop back to a section to pick up what you missed.

I can't say much about how it compares to the mobile version as I've never played it, but the game runs smoothly for me and I have not encountered any bugs.

Overall, it was an enjoyable experience. I would say the game is one of the better point-and-click games available on Steam. It's worth a try if you have it. If you are interested and don't have it, wait until a sale to pick it up.

Joe was just a normal guy, doing a normal job during 1972. It would seem fate had different plans for him. The Silent Age is classic science fiction mixed with fantastic puzzle solving. Using a portable time machine you will bounce through realities trying to find out whats going on and how you are connected to it all. The art direction is a clash of post apocalyptic and groovy 70's design. From over the top wallpapers to overgrown flora and dilapidated buildings. While The Silent Age isn't the most complicated game in the world, the elements it does bring are done well, from the music, UI, and even controller support. For me this game was comfort food and was familiar. The puzzles were challenging enough but didn't grind progression to a halt. As far as it being a port goes, the graphics have been overhauled and look great, and voice work where present is well done and I was happy to hear it. The only complaint I could muster is that the game a little bit on the short side, probably taking 2 to 4 hours at the most to complete. That isn't totally a bad thing but I guess I just wanted more.

The full (German) review can be found here: http://www.jack-reviews.com/2015/05/the-silent-age-review.html

The Silent Age is a solid time travel adventure that only really suffers from its sub-par presentation. The protagonist can only walk left and right, never turns around, doors just fade out of existence, flashbacks are told in still images ... not exactly horrible, but it could have been better. At least the voice acting is good. And the story, while not particularly creative, is also fine. Could have used a different ending, though.

For a game originally released on mobiles, the gameplay works quite well. It's simple and easy, sure, but that's still better than it being difficult or wonky. To solve puzzles, you have to jump between the present and the future. All you need is to click on the time machine and there you go. A swift transition without unnecessary effects.

But the speed is hampered by descriptions that take literally forever to appear. It's like they're trying to prolong an otherwise short experience. 2 or 3 hours and that's it. Might be too short for a couple of people, but it never seemed rushed or anything.

So should you buy The Silent Age? Maybe. It's not amazing, but it also isn't bad.

reviewText:
The Silent Age  is a point and click with a quite rare central mechanic - in the majority of the game it's possible to timetravel - changing past affects the future, and you can take items with you.
The game was originally a mobile game, which got revamped, and it's mobile past shows - there is no item combination, has 10 shorter chapters to support shorter sessions, no pixelhunting and all items are used only once - these add up to a casual, easy, but well-made point and click game with really nice voice acting quality.
The developers recently added several (six!) new supported languages, and the patch broke the achievements -  after we mentioned it on the forums, in two days they patched it, they work fine. To be honest I don't understand why they didn't reply to us, or featured it as news, even though their patch caused the whole issue, they fixed it nicely really fast - good support is a valuable thing.

Things that may deter you from purchasing, depending on your preferations:
- Game has 10 chapters, each around half an hour if you play for the first time, maybe somewhat more. This is considered to be a short point and click, and it's easy as well - if you want a more challenging, or longer game, you should stay away.
- The game features time travel, so it does what every story, movie, book every that features timetravel heavily: messes it up.  Any change you make in the past is really focused on the future, always calculable - the hole won't get fixed, buried, covered etc, and never will have extra consequences. So if you're going for a very logical, almost realistic story, this game isn't really your thing.
If you're okay with these, feel free to get the game! Not the longest, not the most realistic/serious ones, but it's quite likeable, perfect for players who want a point and click with more emphasis on story, and won't get you stuck for hours with a puzzle - the protagonist isn't the sharpest tool in the shed and pretty clueless in some situations, so prepare for some funny descriptions about items or actions!

reviewText:
There are theories that suggest that time travel is indeed possible. They are only theories and there are still many open questions regarding what exactly would happen if certain time travel scenarios were realized such as the grandfather paradox. It is precisely those mysteries and unknowns that make time travel so fascinating. It’s great to know the answers, but it also makes things less exciting. That’s just human nature. And that’s why the premise of The Silent Age is so interesting, especially since it explores time travel both in its narrative and gameplay.

The Silent Age is a point-and-click adventure game set in 1972 in which you play as Joe, a janitor who works for a huge corporation called Archon. Through an unfortunate series of events, Joe gets his hands on a handheld time travel device which he can use to travel 40 years into the future. Joe quickly realizes not all is well in 2012. In fact, something has gone horribly wrong and mankind has suffered through a global extinction event. It’s up to Joe to piece things together and try to find out what exactly happened. The story is interesting from the outset and the writing is very good. It is obviously very much influenced by Twelve Monkeys. As is the case in all adventure games, Joe will offer his insight when clicking on different objects, but what I found to be a really nice touch were the unique lines of dialogue when you try to combine objects incorrectly. When you try to bring a torch to an oil barrel, Joe won’t just use a generic reply such as “No, this won’t work”, he will refer to the insanity of lighting a barrel of oil on fire.

I found the puzzle design to be a real treat. Some hardcore adventure fans might find the puzzles too easy, and they are definitely not as hard as in most adventure games we remember from the 80’s and 90’s, but I don’t necessarily see that as a negative. It’s the design that matters, not the difficulty. There’s no value in illogical puzzles that require you to get into the mind of the developer in order to solve them. The Silent Age’s puzzles shine because they are logical and make perfect sense. They also keep the pace flowing, you don’t want your players stuck on a puzzle for hours on end. It hurts the pace of the story and frustrates players. The best puzzles in the game require you to jump back and forth from 1972 and 2012. For example, when Joe needed an apple, he gathered some soil and seeds and placed them under a water source in 1972. When he shifted to 2012, he found an apple tree and literally picked the fruits of his labor.

The game employs a fantastic art style that is both visually striking and also supports the design brilliantly as it pretty much alleviates any pixel hunting. The sound design also has to be commended for its dark ambient soundtrack and solid sound effects. The voice acting is mostly good apart from a terrible voice over of a secretary at the very beginning of the game. The game isn’t particularly long, it took me about 4 hours to get through it and I thought it was the perfect length as neither the story or the gameplay outstayed their welcome.

The Silent Age is a great adventure game with engaging, expertly designed puzzles, compelling narrative and fantastic presentation. This kind of focus isn’t seen too often in this genre, the developer obviously had a very clear vision and managed to realize it successfully. Amanita Design became my favorite adventure game developer in recent years thanks to this type of attention to detail and the synergy between puzzle design and art. If House on Fire continues in this direction we’ll have another fantastic modern adventure game developer on our hands.

8 OUT OF 10 (GREAT)

reviewText:
Silent Age is the story of Joe, a janitor guy of a big American corporation, who's at the wrong place at the wrong time. With his security clearance updated due to a recent promotion he finds himself in the sublevels of the company building and before he could say mop and sponge he discovers a dying man who tasks him with the saving of the world.

Now, what is interesting in this game is the time controlling device you have in your inventory throughout the game. This device allows Joe to switch back and forth between 1972 and 2012. Bothered by a door that is bolted shut and does not let you through? If you travel to the future it will probably be rusted enough for you to kick it in. Similar, not-too-difficult puzzles make this game captivating all the way through to the - for me, at least - surprising ending.

Graphics, voiceover and sound effects are decent enough but it is the game's atmosphere that makes it very good. Currently, it's only 2.5 euros which is not much for seeing a desperate attempt of a janitor guy to save mankind through the end.

reviewText:
Classic SF, with the main themes being the end of mankind and civilization, and time travel - all seen through the eyes of one of the most iconic (and seldomly used) protagonists of the genre, the janitor. Enjoyable and certainly something a little different from what's usually on the menu of games, and adventures in particular - alternating between the 70s and the ruined remains of society in the present.

Not especially long, it betrays its episodic lineage by having chapters, that are effectively different areas, entirely sealed off one from another, so puzzles can never span across them, and the items leading to the solutions must always be found in relative vicinity, making the process easier than most adventure games and more puzzle-y.

For some this might be 'too easy', for me it was pleasantly absent of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. I more or less quit adventure games long time ago, because I didn't like that the only way forward seemed to be either bruteforcing your way through, or giving up and consulting a walkthrough. All in all, my re-introduction to point & click adventures started well.

I enjoy point and click adventure games and picked up The Silent Age on sale on a whim, not expecting much. reviewText:
Short version: 83%The Silent Age is a short, segmented puzzle/adventure game with basic, yet clever time travel mechanics, and a surprisingly engaging story with one of the most everyday protagonist in video game history.

Long version:Meet Joe. Joe is your average, shy, middle-aged white American in the early 1970s. Joe works as a janitor for a stereotypical US firm so low in the company food chain that even his boss doesn’t know his name.

Joe is also involved in a time travel experiment that is about the wipe the human race from the face of the Earth within a day.

This may sound far-fetched, but the premise is handled with a very down-to-earth mentality, which is also reflected in the clean, straightforward plotting and the similarly simple, sharp visual style.

Silent Age is not a classic style point ‘n’ click but one that is a lot closer to a smartphone title. Therefore, it is more of a puzzle game with a plot, since it is divided to ten self-contained chapters, where your goal is to explore the available 2-4 locations and find the correct items and hotspots to progress.
This segmentation carries the drawback of using dialogues somewhat in a plot dump manner, but not in an obnoxious way. The larger problem may be the length: since all chapters are short, the entire game is barely 2 hours long in return, which may scare away people with tighter wallets.

Time travel is a big part of the gameplay, and is really well done here. You are required to switch back and forth between an inhabited environment to a post-apocolapytic environment tons during the game. This is handled very well, and makes puzzles twice as fun.

Perfect litmus test for adventure game newbies to find out if inventory-based adventure games are up their alley.\nThe Silent Age is a clean, straightforward, and succinctly written science-fiction adventure where you solve puzzles as the oafish but affable janitor Joe. In an effort to be spoiler-free
date:
let's just say, like many adventure game protagonists, Joe is thrust into situations and environments he is not prepared for and that require clever thinking to overcome.

The puzzles in this game largely escape absurdist Adventure Game Logic, and by doing so are very logical. In being logical, however, some puzzles are occasionally too obvious, but others alternately take a bit of outside thinking or real-world knowledge to solve. There is no need for real inventory management to combine items or anything, as you are typically only solving one or two puzzles at any given moment, and when you use an item it disappears from your inventory. Unlike other adventure games, the need for a guide here is highly unlikely and the puzzles won't leave you frustrated.

Much like its puzzles, the game's user interface is intuitive and logical. The mouse cursor controls everything, be it moving Joe around, looking, using, or picking up items. This is a good game to play with one hand and reward yourself with a tasty beverage in the other.

Something I feel that might be overlooked in the game is its intensely dry humor. Reminiscent of older adventure games, most things Joe has to say are really funny, but are not written as a 'haha' joke. They are just genuinely clever/insightful quips filtered through the lovable dolt of a protagonist.

A downside to the game is it is not very long. I was able to finish it (with 100% achievements) in less than 4 hours. The game takes place over 10 stages
recommended: and the puzzles/items are isolated stage-to-stage, so anything you pick up in a stage will be used in that stage. While I enjoyed the experience during that time, it may be worth waiting for a sale to get a better price/gameplay hours ratio if that is important to you.\n\nAll in all, I think The Silent Age is a great (but short) game that offers some interesting gameplay mechanics but also does not reinvent any wheels. I would recommend this to newbie adventure game players and fans of the genre who would like a light adventure, but hardcore fans of the genre may find it too basic.

reviewText: The Silent Age is a retro-style point-and-click retro 70's adventure. It has retro-style minimalist artwork, and... no. Stop. The Silent Age attempts to capture some of the darker corners of the '70's - the brutality that resulted from the Cold War, the greed of the men who tried to take advantage of it, and their combined consequences. The puzzles aren't especially challenging, and you can't exactly say that it's one of those adventure games that's eschews puzzles to tell a story, because the story isn't amazing, either. But it is still compelling, if point-and-clicks are your jam, and the artwork is very well-done. A lot of the elements look flat, like paper cutouts, relying on shading to give them texture and dimension, and this non-descript artwork plays into the theme of an anonymous hero (literally

So I picked up this little game on sale, and despite the relatively short playtime (I finished the game in three hours), it was worth it for the low price. Here's a quick list of the pros and cons of the game for anyone interested:

+ A brilliant storyline that's complex, interesting and engaging. Clearly a lot of time went into thinking of it.

+ Really good voice acting. I assumed there'd be none, but was surprised when I found there was, and it was good.

- Some puzzles are very difficult to figure out, and I wouldn't have ever been able to solve them without a walkthrough.
- The ending is somewhat anti-climactic and underwhelming, but I'm glad it wasn't too pessemistic, which is what I was expecting.

Overall, I'd give this game a 7/10 and I'd recommend picking it up when it's on sale.

This brings me on to the music. Ahh. The music. It all fits so well with the game and only adds to the atmosphere. Why they havnt released an official OST I dont know. As i have mentioned already, the sound design and OST add a really haunting feeling, which fits with the whole game so well.

The game was great, I had great fun playing it. I thought the art style, storyline, and mechanics of the game fantastic. I loved all the different things you could interact with, espicially when you tries to get Joe to shoot the people. It was very interesting and the only thing I wish is that there would be more detail on what happened to Joe after he woke up in the 21st century. Other than that it was great and I will definetly make my friends play it.

You play as Joe, a not unsympathetic average guy characterized by a very low level of ambition, who nevertheless gets inadvertently involved in a situation that sends him off to save the world by travelling through time. Yes, you have played this game or read this book before, but The Silent Age manages to pull it off pleasantly for the most part.

The game takes the player on an intriguing but almost too conveniently straightforward adventure. Puzzles are mostly logical and situations generally ease in the right direction, though most of the time the main character's actions feel amply disconnected from the central objective. There's always the right item unambiguously right next to where you need it - and nothing else.

Locations and settings appear somewhat inexpertly designed to serve a single purpose. Every area feels stiffly confined, highly improbable, and only part of an artificial world. They don't immediately feel very natural, yet this all contributes to making the game feel a bit dream-like. For instance, why is there a musician playing in a metro station that's obviously completely blocked to the public?

The use of instantaneous time travel is actually very appealing, letting the player switch between present and future in just one click. The only downside is that it soon becomes overused, often requiring to switch back and forth in every single screen just to move forward (for instance a door is opened in 1972 but closed in 2012). The main character quite literally could go nowhere without the device.

The game's take on time travel is never scientifically rigorous, or even remotely probable, though as that is not essential to the plot it is easily forgiven. Also surprisingly the few other characters that inhabit this world never seem to mind our protagonist zapping in and out of existence right before them. It does have passing references to other genre classics such as Back to the Future.

The art direction is a bit on the simplistic side, consisting of very flat 2D vector artwork with very few animations. Almost naive graphics nevertheless manage to capture a unique mood. Nice clean interface.

There is nothing particularly outstanding about the game but it nevertheless manages to retain an air of mystery throughout. All chapters are self-contained and relatively short. The storyline builds up some amount of tension and momentum but unfortunately ends rather abruptly. It is difficult to mention more without spoiling it so let's only say the underdeveloped ending was something of a let down. Many, many questions remain unanswered, and I was hoping for it to go out with a bang or an unexpected revelation.

If you like easy and short point and click adventures and time travel mysteries, this game can be fun for an evening or two. Best bought while on sale.

reviewText:
TL:DR : this is a pretty decent point and click adventure game where you can use time travel (travelling between the games present in the 1970's to 40 years in the future and then back) to solve puzzles. Its is a bit short but enjoyable nonetheless. Worth picking up for an affordable point and click game with a decent story.

Full version:

Silent Age has you playing as Joe, a lowly janitor in a big corporation building in the 1970's. When Joe's colleague suddenly leaves, Joe finds himself stuck with the extra duties and in doing so discovers a dying old man from the future who warns him of an impending apocalypse that Joe must now try and prevent. Joe is given a time travel device which allows him to jump 40 years into the future and back at the press of a button.

The game revolves around point and click style gameplay where you solve puzzles using items you pick up with the time travel element adding a bit of a twist. For example you might need to open a door in a corridor in the present, you use the time machine to jump forward to the future version of that same corridor, find an item to open the door and go back to the present and use it.

Good points:
- the story is quite enjoyable, and given the that time travel is usually a subject that is either done really well or really bad they've done a good job of it in this game
- the puzzles arent too difficult with most of them having a logical solution rather than extremely abstract ones like some other point and click games. Being able to jump betweem the present and future is kind of cool as well. Being able to see what is a normal building in the present turn into a crumbling wreck littered with skeletons in the future is pretty enjoyable
- this was originally a mobile game and the developers have added improved graphics for pc as well as voice acting rather than just a lazy straight port

Bad points:
- its pretty short (about 3-4 hours) but any longer would have been dragging it out and for its price the length isnt too bad

The bad (or more specifically the annoying):

Conclusion:
Even though the story gets a little predictable at the end, the game is still fun and enjoyable despite some of the drawbacks I have mentioned before. If you like somewhat linear story lines and don't mind not rushing through them then this game is for you.

You play as Joe, a not unsympathetic average guy characterized by a very low level of ambition, who nevertheless gets inadvertently involved in a situation that sends him off to save the world by travelling through time. Yes, you have played this game or read this book before, but The Silent Age manages to pull it off pleasantly for the most part.

The game takes the player on an intriguing but almost too conveniently straightforward adventure. Puzzles are mostly logical and situations generally ease in the right direction, though most of the time the main character's actions feel amply disconnected from the central objective. There's always the right item unambiguously right next to where you need it - and nothing else.

Locations and settings appear somewhat inexpertly designed to serve a single purpose. Every area feels stiffly confined, highly improbable, and only part of an artificial world. They don't immediately feel very natural, yet this all contributes to making the game feel a bit dream-like. For instance, why is there a musician playing in a metro station that's obviously completely blocked to the public?

The use of instantaneous time travel is actually very appealing, letting the player switch between present and future in just one click. The only downside is that it soon becomes overused, often requiring to switch back and forth in every single screen just to move forward (for instance a door is opened in 1972 but closed in 2012). The main character quite literally could go nowhere without the device.

The game's take on time travel is never scientifically rigorous, or even remotely probable, though as that is not essential to the plot it is easily forgiven. Also surprisingly the few other characters that inhabit this world never seem to mind our protagonist zapping in and out of existence right before them. It does have passing references to other genre classics such as Back to the Future.

The art direction is a bit on the simplistic side, consisting of very flat 2D vector artwork with very few animations. Almost naive graphics nevertheless manage to capture a unique mood. Nice clean interface.

There is nothing particularly outstanding about the game but it nevertheless manages to retain an air of mystery throughout. All chapters are self-contained and relatively short. The storyline builds up some amount of tension and momentum but unfortunately ends rather abruptly. It is difficult to mention more without spoiling it so let's only say the underdeveloped ending was something of a let down. Many, many questions remain unanswered, and I was hoping for it to go out with a bang or an unexpected revelation.

If you like easy and short point and click adventures and time travel mysteries, this game can be fun for an evening or two. Best bought while on sale.

You play as Joe, a not unsympathetic average guy characterized by a very low level of ambition, who nevertheless gets inadvertently involved in a situation that sends him off to save the world by travelling through time. Yes, you have played this game or read this book before, but The Silent Age manages to pull it off pleasantly for the most part.

The game takes the player on an intriguing but almost too conveniently straightforward adventure. Puzzles are mostly logical and situations generally ease in the right direction, though most of the time the main character's actions feel amply disconnected from the central objective. There's always the right item unambiguously right next to where you need it - and nothing else.

Locations and settings appear somewhat inexpertly designed to serve a single purpose. Every area feels stiffly confined, highly improbable, and only part of an artificial world. They don't immediately feel very natural, yet this all contributes to making the game feel a bit dream-like. For instance, why is there a musician playing in a metro station that's obviously completely blocked to the public?

The use of instantaneous time travel is actually very appealing, letting the player switch between present and future in just one click. The only downside is that it soon becomes overused, often requiring to switch back and forth in every single screen just to move forward (for instance a door is opened in 1972 but closed in 2012). The main character quite literally could go nowhere without the device.

The game's take on time travel is never scientifically rigorous, or even remotely probable, though as that is not essential to the plot it is easily forgiven. Also surprisingly the few other characters that inhabit this world never seem to mind our protagonist zapping in and out of existence right before them. It does have passing references to other genre classics such as Back to the Future.

The art direction is a bit on the simplistic side, consisting of very flat 2D vector artwork with very few animations. Almost naive graphics nevertheless manage to capture a unique mood. Nice clean interface.

There is nothing particularly outstanding about the game but it nevertheless manages to retain an air of mystery throughout. All chapters are self-contained and relatively short. The storyline builds up some amount of tension and momentum but unfortunately ends rather abruptly. It is difficult to mention more without spoiling it so let's only say the underdeveloped ending was something of a let down. Many, many questions remain unanswered, and I was hoping for it to go out with a bang or an unexpected revelation.

If you like easy and short point and click adventures and time travel mysteries, this game can be fun for an evening or two. Best bought while on sale.
